Samples Mn (at.%) O (at.%) Mn4+/(Mn2++ Mn3++Mn4+)(%) Oβ/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ)(%) Mn4+ (at.%) Oβ (at.%) Mn/TiO2 4.83 87.07 72.0 58 3.48 50.50 Zn-Mn/TiO2 3.37 87.90 59.0 43 1.99 37.80 Pb-Mn/TiO2 4.24 91.23 66.0 48 2.80 43.79 The poisoning effect of heavy metals doping on Mn/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 Rui-tang Guo a b ⁎ Qing-shan Wang a b Wei-guo Pan a b Qi-lin Chen a b Hong-lei Ding a b Xue-feng Yin c ⁎⁎ Ning-zhi Yang a b Chen-zi Lu a b Shu-xian Wang a b Yi-chao Yuan d a School of Energy Source and Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai University of Electric Power, Shanghai, PR China School of Energy Source and Mechanical Engineering Shanghai University of Electric Power Shanghai PR China b Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Power Generation Environment Protection, Shanghai, PR China Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Power Generation Environment Protection Shanghai PR China c Environment and Resource college, Inner Mongolia University, Huhhot, Inner Mongolia, PR China Environment and Resource college Inner Mongolia University Inner Mongolia Huhhot PR China d Shanghai Key Laboratory of Multiphase Flow and Heat Transfer in Power Engineering, Shanghai, PR China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Multiphase Flow and Heat Transfer in Power Engineering Shanghai PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Power Generation Environment Protection, Shanghai, PR China. Fax: +86 21 65430410 352. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +86 471 4991460. Graphical abstract Heavy metals have been proven to be of deactivation effect on SCR catalyst. In this paper, the poisoning effect of heavy metals (Zn and Pb) on Mn/TiO2 catalyst was investigated based on experimental and theoretical study. It was found that both of Zn and Pb had a poisoning effect on Mn/TiO2 catalyst and the poisoning effect of Zn was more obvious. The characterization results indicated that the doping of heavy metals on Mn/TiO2 surface would lead to a great decrease of reducibility, surface acidity and NO adsorption ability. The results of XPS characterization revealed the decrease of Mn4+ atomic concentration and chemisorbed oxygen species caused by the doping of heavy metals. Based on the above mentioned unfavorable properties, the doping of heavy metals would cause a serious deactivation of Mn/TiO2 catalyst. From the results of DFT calculations, it could be concluded that the doping of heavy metals on Mn/TiO2 catalyst resulting in a great decrease of NH3 adsorption capacity and NO adsorption ability, which agrees well with the experimental results. Keywords Mn/TiO2 catalyst Deactivation Zn Pb Characterization DFT 1 Introduction As the most effective method for controlling NOx emission from stationary resources such as coal-fired boilers, biomass boilers and municipal solid waste incinerators, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) process has been put into widely commercial utilization during the past several decades [1,2]. However, there are some drawbacks associated with the commercial catalyst (V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2), for example, the deactivation by SO2 and dust present in the flue gas, the formation of N2O at high temperature and the toxicity of vanadia, which raising the requirement for developing new environmental-friendly SCR catalyst with high activity and selectivity for NOx removal [3–5]. Several transitional metals, such as Mn, Ce, Cu, Fe, have been proven to be active for SCR of NO with NH3 [4–10]. It is well known that heavy metals contained in the flue gas from coal-fired power plants could cause the deactivation of vanadium-based SCR catalysts [11–12]. The SCR reactor using low temperature catalyst may be set in the downstream of electrostatic precipitator (ESP), but due to the low collection efficiency of aerosol particles for ESP, the deactivation effect of heavy metals in the aerosol particles on low temperature SCR catalyst should also be taken into consideration. It is well recognized that Pb is the main heavy metal in the flue gas of waste incinerator [13,14]. As for biomass boilers, Zn is the main heavy metal component in its flue gas [15]. However, little effort has been put into the study on low temperature SCR catalyst deactivation resulted from heavy metals. As the typical heavy metals in power plant flue gas, the poisoning effect of Pb and Zn on the performance of low-temperature SCR catalyst still needs further study. In our previous study, the poisoning effect of Zn and Pb on Ce/TiO2 catalyst has been investigated [5]. But the different poisoning effect of Zn and Pb has not been explained theoretically. Therefore, in this work, the deactivation mechanism of Zn and Pb on Mn/TiO2 was investigated based on experimental and theoretical (density functional theory calculations, DFT) studies. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Mn/TiO2 catalyst was prepared as follows: Mn(NO3)2(0.03mol), butyl titanate (0.1mol), ethanol (0.8mol), and water (0.6mol) were mixed under vigorous stirring at room temperature to form transparent yellow sol. After dried at 80°C for 24h, xerogel would come into being. Then the xerogel was calcined at 550°C in air for 6h to obtain the Mn/TiO2 catalyst. The Zn or Pb loaded Mn/TiO2 catalyst was prepared by impregnating the Mn/TiO2 catalyst in the solution of Zn(NO3)2 or Pb(NO3)2 of the required concentration. The molar ratio of Zn:Mn or Pb:Mn was all set as 0.5:1. After that, the mixture was dried at 80°C for 24h and calcined at 550°C in air for 6h. The Zn-loaded and Pb-loaded catalysts are denoted as Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/TiO2, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization A Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-AG system was used to measure the textural properties of the catalyst samples at −196°C. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The temperature programmed reduction by hydrogen (H2-TPR), temperature programmed desorption by NH3 (NH3-TPD) and temperature programmed desorption by NO(NO-TPD) were carried out on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-C chemisorption analyzer. The signal of H2, NH3 or NO was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). To investigate the chemical states of the elements on the surface of the catalyst samples, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was performed on at room temperature using a Thermal ESCALAB 250 spectrometer Al Kα X-rays. The binding energy (BE) was calibrated internally by the carbon deposit C 1s BE at 284.8eV. 2.3 Activity test The SCR activity measurements were performed on a fixed bed reactor made of stainless steel (i.d. 8mm). The simulated flue gas is consisted of 600ppm NO, 600ppm NH3, 5% O2 and balance with Ar. In each experimental run, the catalysts load in the reactor was 0.55cm3 and the gas hourly pace velocity (GHSV) was kept at 108,000h−1. For this system, the concentrations of NO and NO2 was monitored by a NO–NO2–NOx analyzer (Thermo, Model 42 i-HL), and the concentration of N2O was monitored by using a Gasmet Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) gas analyzer (DX-4000). The similar reaction conditions were adopted to study the oxidation of NO on the three catalyst samples, in which NH3 was not introduced in the inlet gas mixture. NO conversion to NO2 was calculated by the following equation: (1) NO conversion to NO 2 = [ NO 2 ] out [ NOx ] out where [NO2] out and [NOx]out are the concentrations of NO2 and NOx in the outlet flue gas, respectively. 2.4 Computational details All calculations are based on density functional theory (DFT) by using Materials Studio (MS) Modeling DMol3 from Accelrys (version 6.0). The (001) surface of anatase TiO2 plays an important role and has been widely studied by experimental and theoretical [16–18] in SCR reaction. Therefore, we choose (001) surface to represent the catalyst surface. Two layers are used to calculate and all atoms are relaxed. No MnO2 crystals were detected in the Mn/TiO2 catalyst from the XRD results. Consequently the Mn atom replaces Ti atom in our work. The double-numerical plus polarization (DNP) functions and (GGA-PBE) [19,20] are used in all calculations. The core electrons are treated with DFT Semi-core Pseudopots (DSPP) [21]. The real space cutoff radius is maintained as 5.8Å. A Monkhorst-Pack grid of size of (2×2×1) is used to the surface Brillouin zone of the whole systems. A 20Å vacuum layer in the z-direction was used to avoid interactions of the surfaces. The convergence criteria for energy and displacement of geometry optimization were set as 1×10−5 Ha and 5×10−3 Å, respectively. Adsorption energies (Ead) of NO molecule are calculated as follows: (2) E ad = E NO surface − E surface − E NO where ENO/surface is the total energy of the same molecule adsorbed on surface, E surface is the energy of pure surface, ENO is the energy of an isolated NO molecule. Note that more negative adsorption energy means a stronger binding of NO on the surface. Based on the similar method, the adsorption energies of NH3 molecule can also be calculated. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity The effect of Zn and Pb doping on the activity for Mn/TiO2 catalyst at different reaction temperature is illustrated in Fig. 1 . It is clear that both of Zn and Pb have a poisoning effect on Mn/TiO2 catalyst, and the poisoning effect of Zn is more serious than that of Pb. For example, the NO conversion on Mn/TiO2 at 180°C is 99.9%, while the corresponding values on Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/TiO2 are only 43.8% and 57.6%, respectively. 3.2 Effect of Zn or Pb doping amount on the catalytic activity of Mn/TiO2 catalyst The effect of Zn or Pb doping amount on the catalytic performance of Mn/TiO2 catalyst at 200°C is illustrated in Fig. 2 . As presented in Fig. 2, the SCR activities of Mn/TiO2 catalyst decrease with the increasing doping amount of Zn or Pb. For instance, when the molar ratio of Zn/Mn is 0.25, the SCR activity is 76.7%, correspondingly, when the ratio is 0.75, the SCR activity is only 37.7%. Moreover, the SCR activity of Pb-doped catalyst is higher than that of Zn-doped catalyst at the same doping amount, that is to say, the poisoning effect of Zn is more serious than that of Pb, as mentioned above. 3.3 BET and XRD measurements The textural properties of the three catalyst samples are summarized in Table 1 . As can be seen from Table 1, the doping of Zn or Pb would lead to a sharp decrease of surface area and total pore volume, which may be resulted from the black of microspores and the agglomeration of catalyst during the loading process of Zn or Pb on Mn/TiO2 catalyst [5]. XRD analysis was used to investigate the crystal structures of the three catalyst samples and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . For Mn/TiO2, no obvious diffraction peaks for Mn and Ti could be detected, suggesting that Mn/TiO2 is inherently amorphous in structure. And the presence of amorphous Mn species has been proven to promote SCR reaction [22]. For Pb-Mn/TiO2, only weak diffraction peak of rutile TiO2 could be found. This indicates the good dispersion of Mn and Pb on TiO2 surface. As for Zn-Mn/TiO2, several diffraction peaks of rutile TiO2 and anatase TiO2 could be observed, and the intensities of TiO2 in Zn-Mn/TiO2 are higher than that in Pb-Mn/TiO2. Therefore, the relatively high crystallinity of TiO2 in Pb-Mn/TiO2 and Zn-Mn/TiO2 might partly contribute to their low SCR activities. 3.4 H2-TPR analysis The results of H2-TPR analysis of the three catalyst samples are shown in Fig. 4 . As can be seen from Fig. 4, there are two reduction peaks in the TPR curve of each catalyst sample. For Mn/TiO2 the first reduction peak at about 340°C could be attributed to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 [1,23,24]; and the second peak around 425°C could be assigned to the reduction of Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 [1,23–26]. For Pb-Mn/TiO2, the first peak is at about 380°C, which belongs to the reduction steps of MnO2 →Mn2O3 and Mn2O3 →Mn3O4 [27], and the second one at about 485°C represents the reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO [27]. The two reduction peaks in the profile of Zn-Mn/TiO2 are of the similar nature with that in the profile of Pb-Mn/TiO2. From Fig. 4, it is noticeable that the reduction peaks in the profiles of the two poisoned catalyst shift to a higher temperature, that is to say, the doping of Zn or Pb could lead to the stabilization of Mn species and make it less reducible. And the reducibilities of the three catalyst samples are in the following order: Mn/ TiO2 >Pb–Mn/TiO2 >Zn–Mn/TiO2, which is in accordance with their SCR performance. 3.5 NH3-TPD analysis The decrease of surface acidity is regarded as one of the main reason for the deactivation of SCR catalysts doped by heavy metals [5,12]. To study the surface acidity of the catalyst samples, NH3-TPD analysis was performed and the results are presented in Fig. 5 . One continuous broad peak lasting from 120°C to 500°C could be observed in the profile of Mn/TiO2 catalyst, which could be attributed to the successive desorption of ammonia adsorbed on Brönsted acid sites [26]. Brönsted acid sites can provide sites for generating N H 4 + , which can react with NOx to produce N2 and promote SCR reaction [28]. After the doping of Zn or Pb, the peak decreases greatly, indicating that the addition of heavy metals strongly inhibits the adsorption of NH3. The calculated surface acidity for different catalyst samples are listed in Table 2 . Because the three catalyst samples are of different BET surface areas, so the intrinsic surface acidities were determined by normalizing the total surface acidity by the BET surface area and the results are also listed in Table 2. It is noticeable that the intrinsic surface acidities of Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/ZiO2 are higher than that of Mn/TiO2. Therefore, it may be concluded that the decrease of surface area is the main reason for the decline of NH3 adsorption capacities of Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/TiO2. The result is in accordance with our previous study [5]. And the decrease of surface acidity of SCR catalyst caused by the physical covering of PbO was also pointed by Gao et al. [11]. 3.6 NO-TPD analysis The results of NO-TPD analysis are presented in Fig. 6 . From Fig. 6, we can see that there are two broad desorption peaks in the profile of each catalyst sample. The peaks observed below 450°C should be linked to weakly or physical adsorbed NO, and the peaks above 500°C should be contributed to the decomposition of nitrate formed on catalyst surface [26]. For Mn/TiO2 catalyst, the area of the desorption peaks is the largest, which means that the amount of NO adsorbed on the surface of Mn/TiO2 is obviously greater than that on Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/TiO2. Therefore, we may conclude that the doping of Zn or Pb would lead to the decrease of NO adsorption ability of Mn/TiO2 catalyst. 3.7 XPS analysis XPS analysis was carried out to investigate the surface nature and element concentration. The XPS spectra of Mn 2p3/2 over different catalyst samples are shown in Fig. 7 . The XPS spectra of Mn 2p3/2 can be divided into three peaks corresponding to Mn4+, Mn3+ and Mn2+, respectively [29,30]. Combined with the results of H2-TPR analysis, the redox abilities of the catalyst samples mainly come from the transformation of Mn species with different valence state. According to the XPS analysis results, the ratios of Mn4+/(Mn2+ +Mn3+ +Mn4+) over Mn/TiO2, Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/TiO2 are presented as 72.0%, 59.0% and 66.0%. From Table 3 , it can be seen that the total Mn concentrations over the catalyst samples are 4.83 at.%, 3.37 at.% and 4.24 at.%. Thus the Mn4+ concentrations over Mn/TiO2, Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/TiO2 are calculated to be 3.48 at.%, 1.99 at.% and 2.80 at.%, respectively. Therefore, it can be concluded that the addition of Zn or Pb would lead to a decrease of Mn4+ concentration. It is well recognized that Mn4+ can promote the oxidation of NO to NO2, which is helpful to SCR reaction [31]. From the results of H2-TPR analysis, Mn4+ makes a great contribution to the reducibilities of the catalyst samples. It has been reported that the redox process of Mn4+ also plays an important role in low temperature SCR reaction [32]. So the decrease of Mn4+ concentration on the surface of Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/TiO2 might be another inducement for their low SCR activity. The XPS spectra of O1s are shown in Fig. 8 , which can be fitted by three peaks: lattice oxygen Oα(529.0–530.0eV), chemisorbed oxygen Oβ(531.3–531.9eV) and hydroxyl groups Oγ(532.7–533.5eV) [33,34]. Based on the same method mentioned above, the concentrations of Oβ on the surface of each catalyst sample are calculated and the results are presented in Table 3. It has been well recognized that chemisorbed oxygen is the most effective oxygen species in SCR reaction [35]; moreover, the oxygen in the gas phase and oxygen molecule adsorbed on the catalyst surface can easily exchange with chemisorbed oxygen, and the active transportation of chemisorbed oxygen can also facilitate SCR reaction [36]. As shown in Table 3, a distinct decrease of chemisorbed oxygen concentration could be observed after the doping of Zn or Pb, as a result, partly contributing to the bad SCR performance of Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/TiO2. 3.8 Activity of NO oxidation to NO2 The activities for NO oxidation to NO2 on the three catalyst samples were tested and the results are illustrated in Fig. 9 . As shown in Fig. 9, the activity of NO oxidation increases with reaction temperature, that is to say, the NO catalytic oxidation reaction on the three catalyst samples is a kinetically limited process, which agrees well with the study of other researchers [37]. In addition, it is clear that NO oxidation activities on the three catalyst samples are in the following order: Mn/TiO2 >Pb-Mn/TiO2 >Zn-Mn/TiO2, which is in line with their SCR activities. It has been proven that chemisorbed oxygen could promote NO oxidation [31], so the different NO oxidation activities of the three catalyst samples should be resulted from their different chemisorbed oxygen concentrations. Therefore, the results of NO oxidation activity test are consistent with XPS analysis results. 3.9 Optimized structure and NO adsorption ability (theoretical section) As mentioned above, the inhibition of NH3 adsorption on Zn-Mn/TiO2 or Pb-Mn/TiO2 is mainly caused by the decrease of BET surface. So we only studied the effect of Zn or Pb doping on NO adsorption ability of Mn/TiO2 catalyst. The optimized structures of the fresh and heavy metals poisoned Mn/TiO2 catalyst models are shown in Fig. 10 . From the calculated results, it is obvious that the doping of Pb or Zn significantly changes surfaces of TiO2 (001). After doped by heavy metals, the top layer atoms moves seriously and it is clear that Zn has a greater effect than that of Pb. Pb and Zn atoms are all bonded to the O atoms (see Fig. 10), but Zn atom makes the Mn atom move to the opposite site. And the bond lengths of Pb-O and Zn-O are 2.056 and 1.839Å, respectively, which reveals that heavy metals are seriously adsorbed on the surfaces. Furthermore, the Pb atom makes the MnO bond extend and the Zn atom makes one of MnO bond be broken, which is caused by the electrons of Pb atom or Zn atom transfers to the surface of Mn/TiO2. Thus, the electron of Pb atom or Zn atom satisfies the electron orbit of the manganese oxide and weakens the interaction between Mn and O. The Mulliken charge of manganese for fresh Mn/TiO2 (001) surface is +0.886, and after Pb and Zn is doped, the charges of manganese change to +0.963 and +0.948, respectively. Meanwhile, the Mulliken charges of the Pb and Zn atoms are +0.341 and +0.646. From the charge values of Mn and heavy metals we know that the doping of heavy metals leads to the serious ionization of oxygen atoms on the surface, which makes the oxygen vacancy harder to create. It is well recognized that oxygen vacancy is favorable to the formation of chemisorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface and promote SCR reaction [28]. From the different values of charge change, it can be concluded that the poisoning effect of Zn is greater than that of Pb. The adsorption of NO on the three catalyst samples is also investigated based on DFT calculation, and the results are illustrated in Fig. 11 . As can be seen from Fig. 11, NO molecule is bonded to Mn atom and heavy metal atoms. The adsorption energy of NO on fresh catalyst is −47.2kcal/mol, and the NO adsorption energies on Pb-Mn/TiO2 and Zn-Mn/TiO2 are −37.6kcal/mol and −22.1kcal/mol respectively. Thus the doping of Zn or Pb on Mn/TiO2 catalyst would decrease its NO adsorption ability, which is in accordance with the results of NO-TPD analysis. According to the study of Tang et al. [37], the adsorption of NO is the first step for NO catalytic oxidation on Mn/TiO2 catalyst, therefore, the decrease of NO adsorption ability is unfavorable to NO catalytic oxidation, as proved by the experimental results of NO oxidation to NO2. That is to say, the results of DFT calculations provide a valid proof for the experimental results. 4 Conclusions Both of Zn and Pb have a poisoning effect on Mn/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3. Characterization result of XRD revealed that the addition of Zn or Pb to Mn/TiO2 catalyst would cause the growth of TiO2 crystal. Investigation of XPS indicated the decrease of Mn4+ and chemisorbed oxygen concentrations on the surface of Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/TiO2, as a result, resulting in the drop of their redox abilities. And the decrease of surface acidity for Mn/TiO2 after the doping of Zn or Pb is also detected by NH3-TPD analysis. The results of NO-TPD analysis shows that the doping of Zn or Pb could also decrease NO adsorption ability of Mn/TiO2. In a word, the bad SCR performance of Zn-Mn/TiO2 and Pb-Mn/TiO2 might be originated from the growth of TiO2 crystal, the low redox ability, the decreased surface acidity and NO adsorption ability, and the decrease of surface active species, such as Mn4+ and chemisorbed oxygen. The theoretical results agree well with the experimental results. coredata.dc:description: Heavy metals have been proven to be of deactivation effect on SCR catalyst. In this paper, the poisoning effect of heavy metals (Zn and Pb) on Mn/TiO2 catalyst was investigated based on experimental and theoretical study. It was found that both of Zn and Pb had a poisoning effect on Mn/TiO2 catalyst and the poisoning effect of Zn was more obvious. The characterization results indicated that the doping of heavy metals on Mn/TiO2 surface would lead to a great decrease of reducibility, surface acidity and NO adsorption ability. The results of XPS characterization revealed the decrease of Mn4+ atomic concentration and chemisorbed oxygen species caused by the doping of heavy metals. Based on the above mentioned unfavorable properties, the doping of heavy metals would cause a serious deactivation of Mn/TiO2 catalyst. From the results of DFT calculations, it could be concluded that the doping of heavy metals on Mn/TiO2 catalyst resulting in a great decrease of NH3 adsorption capacity and NO adsorption ability, which agrees well with the experimental results.
coredata.dc:title: The poisoning effect of heavy metals doping on Mn/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3
